name: Kepler-30
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-30 Exoplanetary System


Overview

Kepler-30 is a star with 0.99 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.95 times its radius. It is located 3060.4195948 light years away from the solar system and is estimated to be 2 billion years old, as compared to the Sun which is roughly 4.6 billion years old.

Kepler-30 is known to have 3 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the Kepler-30 system

Kepler-30 b

Kepler-30 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the Transit method. The mass of Kepler-30 b is 11.3 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-30 b is 3.9 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, Kepler-30 b is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.


Kepler-30 c

Kepler-30 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the Transit method. The mass of Kepler-30 c is 640 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-30 c is 12.3 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, Kepler-30 c is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system. At more than 50 Earth masses, Kepler-30 c is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.


Kepler-30 d

Kepler-30 d was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the Transit method. The mass of Kepler-30 d is 23.1 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-30 d is 8.8 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, Kepler-30 d is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-30, which contains 3 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
